title: German submarine U-342
text:
German submarine "U-342" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
She was on her first patrol when she was sunk by a Canadian aircraft on 17 April 1944.
She did not sink or damage any ships.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-342" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="AEG">AEG</a> GU 460/8–27 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-342" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and two twin <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> <a href="anti-aircraft%20gun">anti-aircraft gun</a>s. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
The submarine was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 7 December 1941 at the <a href="Nordseewerke">Nordseewerke</a> yard at <a href="Emden">Emden</a> as yard number 214, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 10 November 1942 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 12 January 1943 under the command of "<a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a>" Albert Hossenfelder.
"U-342" served with the <a href="8th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">8th U-boat Flotilla</a>, for training and then with the <a href="7th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">7th flotilla</a> for operations from 1 March 1944.
Patrol.
"U-342" had sailed from <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> in Germany to <a href="Bergen">Bergen</a> in Norway in March 1944, but her patrol began when she departed Bergen on 3 April and headed for the Atlantic Ocean. She had passed through the <a href="GIUK%20gap">gap</a> between <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a> and the <a href="Faroe%20Islands">Faroe Islands</a>, but was attacked and sunk by a Canadian <a href="PBY%20Catalina">Canso</a> (<a href="PBY%20Catalina">PBY Catalina</a>) of <a href="No.%20162%20Squadron%20RCAF">No. 162 Squadron RCAF</a> southwest of Iceland on 17 April.
Fifty-one men died; there were no survivors.
